resource.chars:
Without understating the somewhat unprofitable task 
of giving <s>an<\s> detailed historical account of all that has been 
written upon the Salpae - it may be of interest to 
notice with a view to reconcile a few of the more important discrepancies 
<s>with <\s> among the statements of the chief investigators 
And first;
<u>Of the sides and ends of the Salpae <\u> On so simple 
a matter as this almost every writer has different 
views - Cuvier calls the ganglionic surface 
ventral - the opposite dorsal - the nuclear end
anterior the opposite posterior - Savigny appears 
to follow him - Chamisso follows  Cuvier as to 
the anterior & posterior ends but reverses the dorsal 
& ventral sides 
MM. Quoy & Gaimard - give the ganglionic end as 
anterior the nuclear as posterior - the nuclear side 
as <s>[text?]<\s> ventral the ganglionic as dorsal 
Meyen gives the same determination -
Eschricht considers the nuclear end to be posterior 
the ganglion side - ventral - as also Sars 
M. Milne Edwards seems to follow Chamisso -
It is much to be wished that some uniform 
nomenclature could be adopted. The reasons for 
the terms used in the present paper have already 
been given -
<u>The Nervous System <\u> -
The nervous system was missed by Cuvier altogether.
Savigny describes the ganglion without recognising its 
true nature as the “tubercule qui dans les ascidies 
est contigu au gros ganglion “
Chamisso describes what appears to be the thickened 
edge of the “ciliated fossa” - and states that Eschscholz
